example.item: "A construction in which the Actor (Agent) is topicalized."

phrase.item: "Juan gave the book to the child."

example.item: "A construction in which the Goal is topicalized."

phrase.item: "Juan gave the book to the child."

example.item: "A construction in which the recipient is topicalized."
"A construction in which the instrument is topicalized."

phrase.item: "Maria cut the mango with the knife."

example.item: "A personal passive construction in which the copular verb 'be' is used."
"A Passive construction which contains reflexive markings."

phrase.item: "The house was built in two months (by people)/They built the house in two months."

example.item: "An intransitive verb is derived from a basically transitive one with the direct object of the transitive verb corresponding to the subject of the intransitive."
"The object of the active retains its old case-marking in the passive, the subject of the active cannot appear in the passive clause, and the passive tends to be semantically active."

phrase.item: "The goat was killed. (by some unspecified person)"

example.item: "Signals that the action proceeds in an ontologically salient way, i.e. that salience is assigned to nominals based on their referen'ts relative real-world capacities to control situations."
"Signals when actions proceed from ontologically less salient to more salient participants."
"Analogous to the ActiveVoice, but can also be used with reflexive verbs."
"Analogous to the MiddleVoice, but can also be used with non-reflexive verbs."
"Targets nominals bearing the instrument semantic role. Its effect is to assign informational salience to these nominals."
"An Antipassive in which the P or logical object is overtly downgraded."

"Blocks the P or logical object (basic absolutive) nominal from being assigned Focus salience. This correlates with the P's morphosyntactic downgrading, whereby it becomes insusceptible to any informational salience assignment."

"Blocks the P or logical object (basic absolutive) nominal from being assigned Focus salience. Topic salience is available for assignment to various arguments, including the P, but Focus salience is always assigned to A, and is therefore inaccessible to P or any other nominal."

phrase.item: "The money, I was the one who gave it to you."

example.item: "The transitive subject takes on properties typical of the basic object. Since in an ergative language the same morphological behaviors accrue to transitive object (P) as to intransitive subject (A), one effect of antipassivization is to dissociate the transitive subject (A) from its usual case assignment, the ergative, and reassign it the absolutive."
"The logical nonsubject takes on properties typical of the basic object."

example.source: Klaiman (1991:17) from Allen, Gardiner and Frantz (1984:304-5)
example.item: "An oblique locative nominal assumes the subject relation."
"A Passive that alters the mapping of a nominal to the Subject relation in a basic intransitive structure."

phrase.item: "(Literally) It is slept by the children."

example.item: "A Passive in which the argument mapped to Object in a basic structural configuration assumes the Subject relation in a corresponding nonbasic configuration."
"Passives that increase the number of actants, as opposed to the protogypical passive, which has the effect of decreasing valency."

phrase.item: "I was deprived of (my) purse by a pickpocket./I had (my) purse stolen."

example.item: "The subject is seen as the "permitter", and is seen (by Comrie1981:164) as having the power to prevent the action."
"The permitter of a permissive construction is not the NP with the greatest control over the action."

phrase.item: "Now son, if you are stronger, you will kill the devils; if you are weaker,you will let the devils kills you."

example.item: "Causatives which use a lexeme as a causative marker."
"Causatives which use a morpheme on the verb as a causative marker."

phrase.item: "By nudging his younger brother, he caused him to fall."

example.item: "Expressing the causation of a number of different actions [with the same causer and causee] within a single sentence."

phrase.item: "The mother asked her daughter to cook food, bring dried fish, and to mend the net."

example.item: "A type of Non-Actor Focus which puts the locative into focus."

phrase.item: "The woman removed (the) shoes from the child."

example.item: "A type of Non-Actor Focus which puts the benefactive into focus."

phrase.item: "The woman removed thorns for the child."

example.item: "Marks 'identified' patients versus 'unidentified' patients. Defined in terms of animacy and definiteness."
"The case marker assigned to the subject of transitive verbs in Ergative languages."
"The case marker assigned to the subject of intransitive and the object of transitive verbs in Ergative languages."

"If the agent outranks the patient on the relevant generic topic hierarchy, the direct-active clause is used. If the relevant norm is reversed and the patient outranks the agent on the relevant hierarchy, the inverse clause is used."
"If the agent is more topical than the patient, the direct-active clause is used. If norm is reversed and the patient is more topical, the inverse clause is used."

phrase.item: "And the elder brother [OBV] told the wild cat [PROX]."

example.item: "The case marker assigned to the subject of transitive verbs in Ergative languages."
"The case marker assigned to the subject of intransitive and the object of transitive verbs in Ergative languages."

"If the agent outranks the patient on the relevant generic topic hierarchy, the direct-active clause is used. If the relevant norm is reversed and the patient outranks the agent on the relevant hierarchy, the inverse clause is used."
"If the agent is more topical than the patient, the direct-active clause is used. If norm is reversed and the patient is more topical, the inverse clause is used."

phrase.item: "And the elder brother [OBV] told the wild cat [PROX]."

example.item: "Associated with transitivity, when the action is performed by an agent (subject) on another participant (object), or with intransitivity."
"Associated with reflexivity and with borrowed verbal roots that would be semantically more compatible with ActiveVoice."
"Associated with actions performed on the subject by an unspecified agent."

phrase.item: "You have had your head load put on (yourself)."

example.item: "Expresses a command to continue an action."
‚ÄúExpresses a peremptory command to begin an action that has not yet been started, with an implied 2ndPerson subject.‚Äù
‚ÄúSimilar to imperative command, except is only used with 1stPerson and 3rd person subject, expresses a peremptory command to begin an action that has not yet begun.‚Äù
"Derives transitive stems from noun roots."

"Derives an intransitive verb from a transitive stem whereby the original agent (only) is cross-referrenced by the absolutive markers on the verb and the original patient, if it appears, is in an oblique phrase."
"Derives transitive stems from positional roots, with the meaning ‚Äòput or leave in the position described by the root."
"Derives intransitive stems."
"Derives transitive stems from transitive and intransitive stems, adding the meaning ‚Äògo and do it‚Äô."
"Derives transitive stems from transitive roots and stems, and positional roots, adding the meaning ‚Äòrepetitive‚Äô to the action."
"Derives intransitive stems from adjectives, with the meaning ‚Äòbecome or take on the quality of the adjective."
"Derives transitive stems from transitive and intransitive stems, adding ‚Äògo‚Äô and the imperative to the meaning."
"Passives that increase the number of actants, as opposed to the protogypical passive, which has the effect of decreasing valency."

phrase.item: "I was deprived of (my) purse by a pickpocket./I had (my) purse stolen."

example.source: Knott (1995:55) from Nedjalkov et al. (1969) in Shibatani (1995)
example.item: "The subject is seen as the "permitter", and is seen (by Comrie1981:164) as having the power to prevent the action."

example.source: Knott (1995:55) from Nedjalkov et al. (1969) in Shibatani (1995)
example.item: "The permitter of a permissive construction is not the NP with the greatest control over the action."

phrase.item: "Now son, if you are stronger, you will kill the devils; if you are weaker,you will let the devils kills you."

example.item: "Causatives which use a lexeme as a causative marker."

example.source: Nejalkov, Otaina and Xolodoviƒç (1995:62) in Shibatani (1995)
example.item: "Causatives which use a morpheme on the verb as a causative marker."

phrase.item: "By nudging his younger brother, he caused him to fall."

example.source: Nejalkov, Otaina and Xolodoviƒç (1995:62) in Shibatani (1995)
example.item: "Expressing the causation of a number of different actions [with the same causer and causee] within a single sentence."

phrase.item: "The mother asked her daughter to cook food, bring dried fish, and to mend the net."

example.item: "A type of Non-Actor Focus which puts the locative into focus."

phrase.item: "The woman removed (the) shoes from the child."

example.item: "A type of Non-Actor Focus which puts the benefactive into focus."

phrase.item: "The woman removed thorns for the child."

example.item: "Marks 'identified' patients versus 'unidentified' patients. Defined in terms of animacy and definiteness."

"The deliberate, potent, active instigator of the predicate: the primary involved doer. Normally the agent is human, and agency is therefore often connected with volition, will, intentionality, and responsibility."

phrase.item: "I gave myself a sore by doing something/I did the sore."

example.item: "When the primary executor of an act has all the characteristics of an agent, but is not the direct cause of the act, the argument is the author. The distinction between agent and author is made to accommodate differences in participation between those arguments that carry out acts for reasons internal to the arguments (agents) and those that carry out acts for noninternal reasons. Semantically authors fall on a gradient between agents and instruments."

"If an argument is the means by which a predicate is carried out, it has the thematic role instrument. Unlike agents and authors, instruments must be acted on by something else in order to participate in the situation; their energy source is external to them."

"If an argument undergoes, is changed by, or is directly affected by a predicate, it is a patient. This choice of terminology reflects the fact that a patient suffers the situation, or comes out changed as a result of the action of the predicate. The patient is the primary recipient of the event."

phrase.item: "The man broke the glass/The glass, it's what the man broke."

example.item: "If a predicate affects the internal state or constitution of an argument, then the argument has the thematic role experiencer. Because internally affected entities have to have an internal state to register the effect, experiencers frequently turn out to be human, or at least animate. But because what counts as an internal state is fuzzy and may be construed differently by a culture or domain of discourse, experiencers are not necessarily animate."
"A recipient that derives actions or entities from the actions of another. Benefactives typically require an agent elsewhere in the predication."

"In the prototypical situation of motion, some entity is displaced as the result of an initiators influence and moves from some resting point along a trajectory, often to another resting point. The displaced entity is the theme of the predication of displacement."
"Language may signal the object displaced in a predication. It is also common for a language to make reference to the point of origin of displacement, this argument is the source."
"The destination of a predication. The endpoints of events, are not restricted to motion predicates."
"The argument that denotes the spatial position of the of the predicate is the locative; it is the site of the predication, or its static position."

phrase.item: "on the windward side of the big island."

example.item: "The arguments that denote the prior conditions of a predication have the thematic role reason. Reasons are connected to the intentions of the agent and as such rely on prior events themselves for their existence. Reasons may thus be said to link other events to a predication by means of the motivation of an agent."
"A language may thematically code the result or consequence of a predicate. An argument with this role is the purpose."

phrase.item: "Fishing equipment/equipment that will be used for fishing."

example.item: "A passive in Irish in which the preposition "at" is used, and a semantic meaning of progressive tense is found."
"A passive in Irish in which the preposition "with" is used, and a semantic meaning of necessity is added."
"A passive in Irish in which the preposition "with" is used, and a semantic meaning of necessity is added."
